noioso, molto noioso

This game, it does just what the title says. It forces newcomers to Go away , for they will be unable to comprehend its rule or even basic structure. The manual might as well have been written in the hieroglyphics used around the time of the game’s creation. “Easy to Learn” they say to most other games that such statement truly applies to, yet this game is not in the slightest. Other than being basically incomprehensible, it barely is a game in itself. While there is some decisions where to put the stones, that’s all the game is, pick up a stone and place it down where you see fit on the board. This game has failed to survive the test of time, only leeching a player base off those whom have mistaken it for some other game, or just have no other game to play.

From the way you treat me, I can see that your middle and last names--a certain verb and a certain reflexive pronoun--are too offensive to be written in a polite setting like this. And so, I must go, Go. From now on, you are Went to me.

Disclaimer: This is a standalone game. Its rating is based on desire to play.

Go is a great game, indubitably. It has survived millennia of gaming evolution and remains popular today as artifical intelligence has finally overcome the best human players. I took great pleasure in watching the battles between humans and AlphaGo, especially with the insightful commentary of Michael Redmond, and the added knowledge of a good friend of mine, who's one of France's very best Go players.

When it comes to design, there's only one thing I would criticize in Go and that is the concept of komi. I find it extremely inelegant, even downright ridiculous when two countries have different ones, and would prefer games to be played in sets of two with players switching colors halfway through. The winner would then be determined by the sum of his two scores.

Overall I would give the design of Go a 8/10 rating, as I find it to be the ultimate strategy game (while Chess would be a great - if not the ultimate - tactics game). Yet I have absolutely no desire to play the game and must rate it a 3/10 according to my criteria.

Not only is Go part of the family of abstract games, which I generally dislike, I also find its huge grid to be very intimidating and very hard to read. The concept of the game is crystal-clear, yet when the board starts to fill and players attack each other, it is very hard for me to read who controls which territory. For this reason I have to rate it even lower than Chess, because at least if I play Chess with somebody as skilled as me I will understand what's happening, whereas a game of Go against my evil twin would result in a series of random moves with a random winner in the end (probably white, because of komi).
I don't like this and I don't know why. Gameplay is so intricate that you "must" play instinctively, so I really should like it. However, Go feels to dry for me.

Intense but abstract, which reduces my interest even though this is one of the great classic games of all time. Advantage: play can be adjusted by handicap stones. Disadvantage: dramatic differences in levels of skill can make it simply boring for both players.
The classic abstract game. The problem is, I'm tired of abstracts. Grew up with them and therefore, just don't get this to the table often enough to justify keeping it.

The exemplary deep abstract game, much, much better than Chess by virtue of the great handicapping mechanic which allows much stronger players to still be challenged playing against (and teaching) weaker players. That said, the time investment needed to learn and improve at Go could be spent having a lot more fun playing many, many other games. It's more a hobby than a game (reading books, playing with stronger players, getting ranked and setting your handicap). Plus I just find playing 2-player abstracts extremely boring and pointless activities.

I'm torn. It's half very good, half fanciest game of nim. There is no strategy in Go: any wrong move puts you in checkmate until your opponent makes his own mistake, so it's more of a very nebulous puzzle. On the other hand, as soon as he does, then the pressure is back on him.

The very good part is the part where a single mistake has huge consequences, resulting in strong and forth. The very bad part is that understanding what is a mistake and why it is a mistake is hopelessly opaque, you have to reverse engineer the entire game from the end (or at best an entire tsumego of dozens of moves). Learning this just isn't rewarding, but the game is good if you overcome that mountain.

Replaces Hex for me, same type of gameplay and same type of punishmnent for mistakes.

2022: Yeah, it's glorified nim but nebulous enough to require years of studies. It's a game of memory and pattern recognition, not a strategy game. The best version of nim i guess. Unlike chess where you need to backtrack to find out when you could have avoided starting. a chain of moves, in go studying the past moves is pointless, you have to study ALL future moves from a specific play if you want to learn anything from it, which is just painful.

2023: having mistakes be so unclear makes it a respectable but ultimately unpleasant game. Still rating it a 6, but when i do play/study it out of my desire to become a well rounded player and being stumped by it, i must say i am not having a good time. Go is a good game for reasons that i hate.

I was surprised that the game is quite complex, but not in terms of rules. The basic rules are easy to learn and only two pieces are used. However, the number of combinations many times more chess combinations making the game more voluminous. As the playing field is filled with chips, there are many options for where to put the next chip.

This is an incredible game - maybe the best game in all history. But it's not a particularly fun game. I would love to master this game - but I'd rather spend the time playing a lot of other things.

best with go friends. handicaps, smaller boards, and capture go are great for newbies, but only a select few will go down the rabbit hole. worth noting, the handicap system is brilliant. playing at a local go meet up group, having a blast. in half a year, i've hit the peak of its bell curve average-- 8kyu-6kyu OGS, and maybe one day i'll reach high dan

go is more interesting and comprehensible than i first thought. it manages to stay mysterious; there's always more to learn, and yet it can be grasped without the tedium of other abstracts! whenever i come back to it and the feeling of how it plays, i think, "damn, it's still great." it’s less memorization and more about patterns, big ideas, and hard calculation. it's the perfect abstract, far better than any i've ever played

edit: dropped from a 10/10 to a 7/10. there's one problem with go: it's alienating. the community often times feels more interested in the game than the players

While I recognize Go as one of the greatest abstract games of all time—right alongside Chess—I don’t find it particularly enjoyable for myself. I lack the “git gud” mentality, and after being thoroughly beaten online by a 10-year-old, I don’t think it will ever become one of my personal favorites.

I like it even though I'm terrible at it. The exemplar of elegance in game rules.

The granddaddy of abstract strategy, Go skirts around the typical pitfalls of perfect-information games by making players feel like they learn something new with every play. Skill level differences between players can still be frustrating, but the game has handicaps for that. It may be THE game with the largest gap between ease of learning and challenge of mastering.

After years of occasionally starting to read a Go book and getting hung up when it told me what was obviously going to happen in a given area, I finally just tried playing a 9x9 game with a friendly stranger. The chance to just go ahead and make mistakes (and still win, because 4 handicap is a lot) and see what happened was enlightening. Now I want a little more.

I made a DIY 19x19 board and bought a set of ceramic stones. The game on 19x19 takes too long for a beginner so I would recommend making a smaller 13x13 (or smaller). As a beginner you tend to make dumb moves as well as repetitive chasing across the board which leaves you in a game across the whole board (one BIG war instead of several small battles). All in all best abstract out there and I've played my part of chess.

Classic. Wanted to learn. I definitely understand why people want to become a master. Very simple, yet very engaging, much more my cup of tea rather than chess. I'll have to try it again as an adult, and I do see the beauty of emergent complexity from very simple rules, but I'm just not really an abstract game person. 5 for now.

Edit: I started playing go puzzles online and I'm starting to see the beauty. I'm bumping it up to a 6.

Edit: Ok it's been a full two weeks of playing and it's fun. Raised to 7.

Edit: it's been a couple months now and I've bought a nice board. The aesthetics of the game are quite something. Such a simple ruleset but so much emergent structure and feeling. You can feel the balance of offence and defence, of tactics and strategy, small scale and large scale, gaining territory and gaining influence, block and flow, black and white, yin and yang. Raised to an 8.

Go is such a beautiful and brilliant game. I have nothing but the utmost respect for it - the few full games I've had the pleasure of playing have challenged me in ways I hadn't thought possible from a board game.

But herein lies my complaint. Go is so huge and so complex that it requires an enormous time commitment. I'm talking 6-8 hours for one 19x19 game, at least for an amateur. As the board becomes more populated, and piece placement carries greater consequence, you find yourself taking more and more time before placing a piece. I just don't have that kind of time to devote to a game regularly.

So, as much as I love Go, I can only enjoy it every once in a while. And that's a shame because it takes regular practice to develop any sort of measurable skill for this game.

Fantastic game, but like chess, requires a huge investment of study time and practice to become really competitive. There's a little too much memorization of opening positions involved in high-level play for my taste.

This one's a classic. What makes it a 10 for me is:

I have enjoyed 2p abstracts (particularly the GIPF series) for a long time, so Go being a bit of a blindspot for me is a source of at least some shame, but I just have never worked myself up to put the dedication required in to truly understanding it. I recently started doing some puzzles on mobile apps and have already fallen out of the habit, but I'd like to return and take cracks at it until it becomes a more stable ongoing practice (both puzzles and games, at least asynchronous or live speed matches on smaller boards). When liberties and shapes finally start to click a bit I do find that it deepens ones ability to read board states and understand/appreciate other games. As much as I admire it though, I don't think I will ever be able to have as much fun with it as I do "shallower" spatial abstract games, and I'm ok with that (being a pleb).

Update: I've recommitted to studying this game and am enjoying it more and more. It really does take a while for things to set in well enough to feel like you are engaging with the game (and I just barely am at this point still).

Go gives strategic freedom and quite a landscape to gain influence on. As a beginner it gives me amazingly simple and intuitive gameplay that promises me a wide array of strategic opportunities while playing. There is beauty and depth in Go's minimalism that I really enjoy.

during a recent visit to Japan, i found myself alone in Tokyo on my last full day before flying home, with no plans. having spent the better part of two weeks traveling and visiting with family, we parted ways and i was left with no obligations to anyone but myself. i could have done almost anything with that time but i chose to spend the afternoon in a Go cafe, playing Go with strangers, and i didn't regret it for a moment. i think that anecdote better captures something of the impossible and compelling nature of the game, and my relationship to it, than anything else i could say

There are a few "lifestyle games" out there, games that captivate you and become a part of your life forever as you pursue better and better play with their depth and endless variations. Go/Baduk/Weiqi is one of these games, and Go has become my lifestyle game. It feels less like a game and more like a language, as you come to understand it more and more. I'm almost a year in and around 1 kyu in rank, and within that year of intense study, consumption and memorization of numerous pro games, lessons I feel like I see a totally different game than when I first started. That said, I have much much much more to see, so much more to experience, and undeniably a lifetime to learn. Within this time Go has changed much of my personal life as I've made friends through it I otherwise wouldn't have, and I am studying Mandarin solely for the game. I have trips planned for the purpose of studying the game with teachers abroad. Of course it's affected my bank account as I've purchased a nice Goban, nice table boards, stones of different make and sizes. The game has an aesthetic few can hold a candle to. However, even if I had the simplest of stones and the cheapest of boards, this game would captivate me to no end. I'm still striving to achieve 1 Dan but I know even after I obtain it I'll be striving for the next rank.

I have a set from Japan that I purchased over thirty years ago: Glass stones, a 2" thick slotted wooden board, and wooden bowls with covers. I learned to play when I was 13 years old on a set I bought at a K&K Toy Store after discovering a book about the game in our local library. Simple rules... but a lifetime to master. I like chess, but I love Go. There is no better game.
Easy to learn, lifetime to master. Math traded Janice Kim intro book x2. Gift to Alex.

A timeless and perfect game. Skylar thinks it's extremely opaque. I think it's perfectly legible. Skylar suspects it's because I'm too bad at the game to understand that it's actually more opaque than I think it is. I don't know. I've played dozens of times. If she's played a handful of times or fewer, I can see how it can still feel opaque. My brain naturally orients better around spatial games regardless. I can see it getting tricky in complicated positions where both players are surrounding each other like Russian dolls and it's not clear who's actually in trouble, but most normal positions are quite interpretable. I was obsessed with this game for like a year or two, read a bunch of books, had a regular opponent to grind out games against (and I tended to win). I'm not "good" by any stretch, but I'm pretty sure I would destroy anyone who's played 10 times or fewer. I have other games in the collection that I consider much more opaque than Go. For example, The Gallerist (or any Lacerda), Wabash Cannonball (or any cube rails game), Pax Renaissance, Le Plateau, and John Company. Imperial, Indonesia, Cavum, and Tokyo Tsukiji Market would probably be up there too, if I ever manage to get them played.
An interesting concept, and it looks gorgeous on the table, but it's a little dry for me. And it takes a lot of study to get good at it.

The more modern board games I learn, the more I appreciate the gameplay-to-rules ratio of chess and Go.

The best way to learn on your own is with "The Conquest of Go" on Steam, start with 9x9, playing one game per day, then move up to 13x13 when you feel ready, and finally move on to 19x19.

I have notes on my wiki about how to quickly teach the game face-to-face that I've compiled from various Reddit comments and blog posts:
https://nathanwailes.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/MTOVT/pages/1...

IMO calling the game "Go" and using the ornamental Asian sets actually kind of does a disservice to the game, I think Westerners might engage with it more if it depicted the board as being a map of a country, with each piece being a little army like those used in Risk.
2 Player

By far the closest game that deserves the name 'perfection'; it's almost impossible to imagine any other game that can possibly surpass this game in terms of perfection. In terms of perfection, Go would be 99/100, while Chess is 9/10

The only reason why this isn't a 10, is because it takes way too long to master; if you think Chess takes effort and patience to be good at it..Go is simply on another level; I'd say Go is roughly about x3 more difficult to learn/to be good at than Chess and it also takes about x5 longer to master.

One interesting thing about Go is that you can really "feel" the personality of a player you are playing Go against in an EXTREME detail; if you do this in Chess it's like you can see and tell your opponent's personality through the lens of blood type system (which has just four options -blood type O, A, B, and AB-; in another words, the unique kind of player that can be grasped/identified while playing Chess from your opponent is far more limited, feels less unique, and in comparison far less pronounced than in Go), whereas when playing Go, players can tell your opponent's personality through lens of MBTI types (16 different unique personalities). Btw, I think both personalities tests (blood type and MBTI) are both silly and meaningless and I believe 99.99% it's meant for fun; I'm just using them as an analogy to show how Go allows you to reveal exactly what type of a player your opponent is (it's usually revealed in a negative way, as in a "how flawed your opponent is in a specific way [too careful, too carelessly aggressive, unreliably inaccurate with his/her plays, etc,] unless your opponent is a very strong player who's near flawless;" of course, you also have to be an extremely deep thinking person with a very sharp observational mind that allows to grasp the details of the specific personality of your opponent that can be demonstrated through a game of Go) which is FAR more varied and multi-layered than Chess can ever be.
